summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against a Donaldsonville, Louisiana man who was convicted of second-degree murder in the March 10, 2012, shooting death of Davonne Solomon.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia, alleges that, on the night of March 10 in Geismar and Gonzales, Louisiana, a group of individuals who were traveling in separate vehicles to attend social gatherings were shot in the chest and face. According to the complaint, the defendants were confronted by a member of the group who described Davonne as a "man with dreads" and "panicked." The complaint alleges that Davonne was not armed with a gun, and that the defendant was wearing a camouflage jacket and had dreadlocks. The complaint further alleges that one of the witnesses, Max Batiste, told the defendant that he saw Davonne running away from the scene of the shooting and that he did not see Davonne. The SEC alleges that the defendants' statements were not true, and the jury found Davonne liable for the loss of her life.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Virginia today announced criminal charges against Davonne and issued a temporary restraining order halting the defendants from further violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The court granted the SEC's motion for a new trial, which is subject to court approval. The case was supervised by Kelly L. Gibson, Chief of the Division of Criminal Investigations. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can also use theÂ SEC's investor.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a related matter, the SEC also issued an Investor Alert about potential insider trading in the securities industry, warning investors to be aware of the unusual trading activity taking place in the brokerage accounts of high-yield brokers.  According to SEC's Complaint, filed under seal on January 9, 2019, the defendant, who is a registered representative of the SEC, was not present at the time of the alleged trading activity, and neither was he present when the alleged insider trading took place.   The complaint charges the defendant with violating Section 17(a)(1) and (3) of The Securities Act of 1933, Section 10 of the Exchange Act, and Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of
